div.l: Seke lay the mauncypull on a malady
Men̄ wenden̄ wyssely that he schuld dye
For which this myller stale both mele ⁊and corne
An hundred tyme mor͗e than̄ he dydde byforne
For there byfor͗e he stale but curtesly
But now he was a thef outrageously
For which þe wardeyn̄ chydde ⁊and made fare
But þ̉erof setteth þe myller not a tare
He kraked fast and seyd hit was not so
Then̄ wer͗e there yonge felowꝰes two
That dwelled in the halle of which y sey
Testyf þey were and lusty to pley
And onely for hur myrth and reverye
Vp on̄ the wardeyn̄ bysely they crye
To yeve hem leve but a lytul stounde
To go to mylle and see hur corne y ground
And hardely þey durst ley hur nekke
The myller schuld not stele hem half a pekke
Of Corne ne by sleight ne forse hem Reve
And at the last þe wardeyn̄ yaffe hem leve
Iohn hight þat one · And Aleyn̄ hight þᵗat other
Of one town̄ were they borne that hight Strother
Ferr͗e in the north y kan̄ not tell wher͗e
This Aleyn̄ maketh redy all his gere
And on a horse þe sak he cast anon̄e
Forth goth Aleyn̄ þe clerk. and also Iohn
With goode swerde and Bocler͗e by his syde
Iohn knew þe wey hym nede no gyde
And at þe mylne þe sak doun̄ he leith
Aleyn̄ spake furst alheyle Symon̄ in feith
How fareth thi fair͗e doughter ⁊and thi wyf
Aleyn̄ welcom̄ quoth Symkyn̄ by my lyf
